title: How to Make Felt Beads

steps.headline: Place the graph paper on a work surface.
steps.description: Measure a rectangle on the paper using the dimensions of 12 x 10cm (5 x 4"). Measure another rectangle on the paper using the dimensions of 12 x 8cm (5 x 3").

steps.headline: Cut these rectangles out.
steps.description: They are now your templates for cutting out the felt pieces.

steps.headline: Pin the paper templates to the felt sheets.
steps.description: Use a different color of felt for each rectangle. Always pin from the corners, to make the most of the felt sheet. The colors must be complementary.

steps.headline: Cut out the felt rectangles.
steps.description: Follow the guidance of the template.

steps.headline: Align the smaller felt rectangle on top of the larger felt rectangle.
steps.description: Match the long sides but on the shorter sides, leave a gap at each end. Spread glue along one of the two gaps, at the end.

steps.headline: Roll the felt into a tube shape.
steps.description: Begin at the side you have placed glue on and simply roll up as firmly as possible.

steps.headline: Just before reaching the other side, squeeze some glue across the gap edge.
steps.description: Hold the roll with your other hand, to prevent it from unraveling. Complete the roll and hold the glued portion in place with rubber bands for a short while, until it adheres properly and the roll won't unravel. Place the rubber bands at even intervals down the roll, so that it dries evenly.

steps.headline: Measure intervals down the roll.
steps.description: Use a fabric marker to mark spaces of 2cm/ 3/4" along the roll. When done, use sharp fabric scissors to cut right through the roll at these marked points. The resulting portions are the felt beads.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: Repeat the above steps to make as many felt beads as you need four your project. You can now use the beads to make jewelry, such as necklaces, bracelets and anklets, or attach them to hair accessories, shoes and belts. These beads are also handy for general use in craft projects.

steps.headline: Take a handful of wool roving.
steps.description: Pull the fibers apart, separating them.

steps.headline: Roll the roving into a ball.
steps.description: Make it as tight as you can but don't worry about flyaway pieces. This ball will end up being about half the size as a bead, so keep this in mind when forming it.

steps.headline: Place the ball onto the felting mat or foam pad.
steps.description: Use a felting tool or needle to start locking the fibers together. Push the tool in and out of the center of the felt ball.

steps.headline: Smooth down flyaway fibers on the ball.
steps.description: Manipulate the loose fibers so that they poke back into the ball and leave a smooth outer layer. When you are happy that the ball is round and as smooth as possible, proceed to wetting it.

steps.headline: Squirt a few drops of the detergent in a bowl or basin.
steps.description: Fill with hot water, as hot as you can stand to put your hands into.

steps.headline: Dip the ball into the water.
steps.description: Then roll it between both of your palms. The fibers will begin to fuse as you roll it. Dip it back in now and then and roll again. Press harder as the ball gets firmer, to firm it even more.

steps.headline: Continue until the bead ball is well formed and tight.
steps.description: This will usually take one to two minutes per ball.

steps.headline: Let it dry.
steps.description: Repeat to make as many felt bead balls as you need.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: Use to make jewelry or crafts.

text: Rolled felt beads Place the graph paper on a work surface. Measure a rectangle on the paper using the dimensions of 12 x 10cm (5 x 4"). Measure another rectangle on the paper using the dimensions of 12 x 8cm (5 x 3"). Cut these rectangles out. They are now your templates for cutting out the felt pieces. Pin the paper templates to the felt sheets. Use a different color of felt for each rectangle. Always pin from the corners, to make the most of the felt sheet. The colors must be complementary. Cut out the felt rectangles. Follow the guidance of the template. Align the smaller felt rectangle on top of the larger felt rectangle. Match the long sides but on the shorter sides, leave a gap at each end. Spread glue along one of the two gaps, at the end. Roll the felt into a tube shape. Begin at the side you have placed glue on and simply roll up as firmly as possible. Just before reaching the other side, squeeze some glue across the gap edge. Hold the roll with your other hand, to prevent it from unraveling. Complete the roll and hold the glued portion in place with rubber bands for a short while, until it adheres properly and the roll won't unravel. Place the rubber bands at even intervals down the roll, so that it dries evenly. Measure intervals down the roll. Use a fabric marker to mark spaces of 2cm/ 3/4" along the roll. When done, use sharp fabric scissors to cut right through the roll at these marked points. The resulting portions are the felt beads. Finished. Repeat the above steps to make as many felt beads as you need four your project. You can now use the beads to make jewelry, such as necklaces, bracelets and anklets, or attach them to hair accessories, shoes and belts. These beads are also handy for general use in craft projects. Felted beads Take a handful of wool roving. Pull the fibers apart, separating them. Roll the roving into a ball. Make it as tight as you can but don't worry about flyaway pieces. This ball will end up being about half the size as a bead, so keep this in mind when forming it. Place the ball onto the felting mat or foam pad. Use a felting tool or needle to start locking the fibers together. Push the tool in and out of the center of the felt ball. Smooth down flyaway fibers on the ball. Manipulate the loose fibers so that they poke back into the ball and leave a smooth outer layer. When you are happy that the ball is round and as smooth as possible, proceed to wetting it. Squirt a few drops of the detergent in a bowl or basin. Fill with hot water, as hot as you can stand to put your hands into. Dip the ball into the water. Then roll it between both of your palms. The fibers will begin to fuse as you roll it. Dip it back in now and then and roll again. Press harder as the ball gets firmer, to firm it even more. Continue until the bead ball is well formed and tight. This will usually take one to two minutes per ball. Let it dry. Repeat to make as many felt bead balls as you need. Finished. Use to make jewelry or crafts.
